privacyLaws.lawName: California Online Privacy Protection Act of 2003
privacyLaws.description: The California Online Privacy Protection Act (CalOPPA) is a state law designed to safeguard the privacy of individuals who use websites and online services. Enacted in 2003, CalOPPA mandates that operators of commercial websites and online services that collect personally identifiable information (PII) from California residents must conspicuously post a privacy policy on their websites. This policy must detail the types of information collected, how it's used, and whether it's shared with third parties.

personalDataCategories: Any other identifier that permits the physical or online contacting of a specific individual

Information concerning a user that the Web site or online service collects online from the user and maintains in personally identifiable form in combination with an identifier described in this subdivision.

individualRights.name: Right to Know what personal information is collected

notice.description: A Web page on which the actual privacy policy is posted if the Web page is the homepage or first significant page after entering the Web site.

dataTransfer.description: Identify the categories of personally identifiable information that the operator collects through the Web site or online service about individual consumers who use or visit its commercial Web site or online service and the categories of third-party persons or entities with whom the operator may share that personally identifiable information.

exemptions.description: Non-commercial websites in California are exempt from CalOPPA.

enforcementAuthority: The State of California Department of Justice
finingAuthority: The Consumer Privacy Fund within the General Fund of the state
penalties: If you fail to comply within the 30-day grace period, you face a maximum penalty of $2,500 per violation.
personalLiability: An operator shall be in violation of this subdivision only if the operator fails to post its policy within 30 days after being notified of noncompliance.

threshold.description: Any commercial website or online service that has access to user's Personally Identifiable Information
